subject: May a thousand alphabets blossom!
msgSnippet: Hi, Paige, I know I ve settled back to just lurking, but these last 3 posts--one of a sample (Yay!) brought me out of my shell. I think we all can agree -- no
messageBody:
Message
Hi, Paige, I know I've settled back to just lurking, but these last 3 posts--one of a sample (Yay!) brought me out of my shell.
I think we all can agree -- no matter if we might like to fantasize about books written in QS, that it's primary attraction is that it's phonetic, logical, and just a cool alternative script.
 
Since our attractions to this strange hobby (and ask anyone who doesn't care--they'll tell you it's strange!) are all personal and varied, it really makes sense that we adapt it to meet our needs. Even Read didn't stay locked into QS as it was, but went on to develop another, somewhat more traditional alphabet. QS is a wonderful gifts as it is, and our group will not let it fade into oblivion. But QS is also something else--a launching pad into our continuous adaptation, invention, and exploration of the possibilities of non-Roman scripts for English (and other!) languages.
 
As for myself, I actually used QS to write my journal for a couple of months, but felt myself wanting something more personal still, and developed a personal shorthand incorporating elements of TO, QS, Gregg shorthand, Forkner shorthand, and my own inventions.  It's still changing a little, but is fairly stable as far as most glyphs go. I just find writing in it strangely satisfying.  I can't explain it.
 
Paige go for it, please present your QS/Shaw fusion!
Jerry, way to go with your Snelsgrift
Chuck, thanks for presenting your QS hand!
People, please post your poems, papers, papyri and paragraphs!
 
May ten thousand samples be posted! May a thousand alphabets blossom!
 
Peace and Love to all,
 
Jon


 
I am hoping I won't have to go that route, but I will if the amount of spam (spams?) increases to the point that it is hampering legitimate communication.  We haven't had a huge number of postings either although I would like to see the level of activity increase.

I would like to have a site where people could practice their Quikscript reading and writing.  I believe practice in reading other's writing is crucial for developing fluency.  Previously, I have noticed that the level of activity on the bulletin boards such as Ikon was very limited.  Not much palaver back and forth ever developed.  Perhaps, we would do better to add short poems and prose pieces to the files section on Reed_Alphabet for newbies to read.  Uploading these sorts of things would also give us an opportunity to critique each other's writing as I doubt many of us are expert Quikscript writers.

These and similar thoughts made it questionable in my mind that the two alphabets could be successfully reunited.  Shavian devotees will not want to give up their familiar letter shapes, and Reed_Alphabet devotees will not want to give up theirs.  For instance, how do we decide whether the symbols for "th" in Shavian be altered to mean "f" and "v" as they are in QS, or should it be the other way round?  I don't feel it practicable to use Shavian for "print" forms and QS for "handwritten" forms as someone wrote a few months back.  I believe the difference between the symbols of the two alphabets can fairly be called cognitive dissonance.  If one is acclimated that a QS "f" represents "f", it slows reading down a great deal, if you have to make the transition to realize it is a "th" in Shavian or vice-versa.  This problem was exacerbated by Reed's recycling of some Shavian symbols by remapping them onto different phonemes in QS.  Perhaps, I am making too much out of this.  Any thoughts?

Paige Gabhart



Chuck Peck wrote:
Hello Paige,
 
I also run a Yahoo group and I finaly had to only allow postings from members. WHen someone requests to become a member I email them directly and try to insure its not a spammer. My group is small and gets only a few postings a month so its not too hard ot keep up with.
 
Chuck

Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...> wrote:
The most recent spam has been deleted from messages and the e-mail
address for one of them has been deleted.  The other one I cannot
find in the list of members so that may be solved as well.  We will
see.

Paige Gabhart


Do you Yahoo!?

Hi, Paige, I know I've settled back to just lurking, but these last 3
posts--one of a sample (Yay!) brought me out of my shell. 
I think we all can agree -- no matter if we might like to fantasize
about books written in QS, that it's primary attraction is that it's
phonetic, logical, and just a cool alternative script. 
 
Since our attractions to this strange hobby (and ask anyone who doesn't
care--they'll tell you it's strange!) are all personal and varied, it
really makes sense that we adapt it to meet our needs. Even Read didn't
stay locked into QS as it was, but went on to develop another, somewhat
more traditional alphabet. QS is a wonderful gifts as it is, and our
group will not let it fade into oblivion. But QS is also something
else--a launching pad into our continuous adaptation, invention, and
exploration of the possibilities of non-Roman scripts for English (and
other!) languages.
 
As for myself, I actually used QS to write my journal for a couple of
months, but felt myself wanting something more personal still, and
developed a personal shorthand incorporating elements of TO, QS, Gregg
shorthand, Forkner shorthand, and my own inventions.  It's still
changing a little, but is fairly stable as far as most glyphs go. I just
find writing in it strangely satisfying.  I can't explain it. 
 
Paige go for it, please present your QS/Shaw fusion!
Jerry, way to go with your Snelsgrift
Chuck, thanks for presenting your QS hand!
People, please post your poems, papers, papyri and paragraphs!
 
May ten thousand samples be posted! May a thousand alphabets blossom!
 
Peace and Love to all,
 
Jon



 
I am hoping I won't have to go that route, but I will if the amount of
spam (spams?) increases to the point that it is hampering legitimate
communication.  We haven't had a huge number of postings either although
I would like to see the level of activity increase.

I would like to have a site where people could practice their Quikscript
reading and writing.  I believe practice in reading other's writing is
crucial for developing fluency.  Previously, I have noticed that the
level of activity on the bulletin boards such as Ikon was very limited.
Not much palaver back and forth ever developed.  Perhaps, we would do
better to add short poems and prose pieces to the files section on
Reed_Alphabet for newbies to read.  Uploading these sorts of things
would also give us an opportunity to critique each other's writing as I
doubt many of us are expert Quikscript writers.

These and similar thoughts made it questionable in my mind that the two
alphabets could be successfully reunited.  Shavian devotees will not
want to give up their familiar letter shapes, and Reed_Alphabet devotees
will not want to give up theirs.  For instance, how do we decide whether
the symbols for "th" in Shavian be altered to mean "f" and "v" as they
are in QS, or should it be the other way round?  I don't feel it
practicable to use Shavian for "print" forms and QS for "handwritten"
forms as someone wrote a few months back.  I believe the difference
between the symbols of the two alphabets can fairly be called cognitive
dissonance.  If one is acclimated that a QS "f" represents "f", it slows
reading down a great deal, if you have to make the transition to realize
it is a "th" in Shavian or vice-versa.  This problem was exacerbated by
Reed's recycling of some Shavian symbols by remapping them onto
different phonemes in QS.  Perhaps, I am making too much out of this.
Any thoughts?

Paige Gabhart
